name: Judas Maccabeus
displayName: Judas Maccabeus - The Hammer of Israel
description: Judas Maccabeus (Hebrew: Yehudah HaMakabi, 'Judah the Hammer') was the third son of the priest Mattathias who led the Jewish revolt against the Seleucid Empire (167-160 BCE). When Antiochus IV Epiphanes desecrated the Temple by sacrificing pigs and erecting a statue of Zeus, Mattathias and his sons ignited a rebellion that combined guerrilla warfare with unwavering zeal for the Torah. Judas emerged as the military commander after his father's death, winning a series of stunning victories against vastly superior Seleucid forces. His recapture and rededication of the Temple in 164 BCE is commemorated in the festival of Hanukkah. For the Zealots of Jesus' time, Judas Maccabeus represented the ideal of armed resistance in defense of God's law - the model they hoped Jesus would follow. Yet Jesus, though called 'Son of David,' proclaimed a kingdom not of this world and conquered through the cross rather than the sword.
shortDescription: The Hammer who led the Maccabean revolt, defeated the Seleucids, and rededicated the Temple - the Zealot ideal of the warrior liberator.

weapons.name: The Sword of Apollonius
weapons.description: Captured from the Seleucid general he defeated, Judas used this sword for the rest of his life

weapons.name: Guerrilla Warfare
weapons.description: Used hit-and-run tactics, night raids, and knowledge of terrain against larger armies

weapons.name: Zeal for the LORD
weapons.description: His greatest weapon - willingness to die rather than abandon Torah

companions: The Hasidim (the Pious Ones who joined the revolt)

quests.name: The Battle of Beth Horon
quests.description: First major victory, defeating Seron and the Syrian army in the mountain pass (166 BCE)

quests.name: The Battle of Emmaus
quests.description: Defeated the general Gorgias with only 3,000 men against 40,000 (165 BCE)

quests.name: The Battle of Beth-zur
quests.description: Defeated Lysias and his massive army, opening the way to Jerusalem (164 BCE)

quests.name: The Rededication of the Temple
quests.description: Cleansed the desecrated Temple and relit the menorah - the origin of Hanukkah (164 BCE)

quests.name: The Defense of Judea
quests.description: Continued campaigns to protect Jewish communities in Galilee and Gilead

quests.name: The Final Stand at Elasa
quests.description: Died in battle against overwhelming Seleucid forces, refusing to flee (160 BCE)

feats: Won multiple victories against armies 10-40 times larger
Made alliance with Rome (first Jewish-Roman treaty)
Killed the Syrian general Apollonius in single combat
Maintained guerrilla resistance in the hills of Judea
Inspired generations of Jewish resistance fighters
United the Hasidim with armed resistance

brothers: Simon Thassi (became High Priest and Ethnarch)
relationships.legacy: Hasmonean Dynasty established by his brothers

primarySources.content: Primary narrative of the Maccabean revolt and Judas's campaigns

primarySources.source: Josephus, Antiquities of the Jews, Book XII
primarySources.content: Later historical account of the Maccabean period
Possibly refers to the Maccabean resistance ('those who know their God shall stand firm')

maccabeanRevolt.cause: Antiochus IV Epiphanes' persecution of Judaism (167 BCE)
desecrations: Banned circumcision on pain of death
Erected statue of Zeus in Temple (Abomination of Desolation)
maccabeanRevolt.spark: Mattathias killed a Jew who was about to offer pagan sacrifice at Modi'in
maccabeanRevolt.rallying_cry: Whoever is for the LORD, follow me! (cf. Exodus 32:26)
maccabeanRevolt.strategy: Guerrilla warfare from the Judean hills
maccabeanRevolt.significance: First successful religious war for freedom of worship in history

hanukkahOrigins.event: Rededication of the Temple after three years of desecration
hanukkahOrigins.miracle_tradition: Oil that should have lasted one day burned for eight
hanukkahOrigins.celebration: Eight-day festival of lights commemorating the rededication
hanukkahOrigins.significance: Triumph of faithful minority over pagan majority, light over darkness

zealotLegacy.description: For the Zealots of Jesus' time, Judas Maccabeus was the model of righteous armed resistance
inspiration: God fights for those who fight for Him
zealot_application: Expected a new Maccabee to arise
Hoped Jesus would be this warrior-liberator
Simon the Zealot may have expected armed uprising

jesus_contrast.maccabean_model: Military victory, political liberation, Temple restoration
jesus_contrast.jesus_way: Suffering servant, spiritual kingdom, Temple of his body
key_texts: My kingdom is not of this world (John 18:36)
Those who live by the sword will die by the sword (Matthew 26:52)

phineasConnection.description: The Maccabees explicitly claimed the mantle of Phinehas
phineasConnection.text: Phinehas our ancestor, by being zealous with great zeal, received the covenant of an everlasting priesthood (1 Maccabees 2:54)
phineasConnection.significance: Violent zeal for God's honor seen as priestly act
phineasConnection.mattathias_action: Like Phinehas, Mattathias killed an apostate Jew at the altar

martyrdom.circumstances: Faced 22,000 Seleucid troops with only 800-3,000 men
martyrdom.choice: Refused to flee, saying 'If our time has come, let us die bravely for our kindred'
martyrdom.death: Fell in battle, fulfilling his father's charge to 'give your lives for the covenant'
martyrdom.burial: Buried in the family tomb at Modi'in with great lamentation
martyrdom.legacy: His brothers Jonathan and Simon continued the fight

judas_as_type: Willing to die for the cause
contrast_with_jesus: Judas fought with sword; Jesus conquered through cross
Judas liberated Jerusalem; Jesus wept over it
Judas cleansed the Temple; Jesus cleansed and replaced it
Judas defeated enemies; Jesus died for enemies
Judas' kingdom was political; Jesus' kingdom is spiritual
typology.simon_the_zealot_perspective: Simon may have hoped Jesus would be the new Maccabee who would drive out Rome as Judas drove out the Greeks. Jesus transformed this zeal from violence against enemies to love for enemies.

listDisplay.secondary: The Hammer who led the revolt against Seleucid oppression and rededicated the Temple
listDisplay.expandedContent: Judas Maccabeus led the successful Jewish revolt against the Seleucid Empire (167-160 BCE), defeating vastly superior forces through guerrilla warfare and zeal for Torah. His rededication of the Temple is commemorated in Hanukkah. For Zealots, he represented the ideal warrior-liberator.

hoverInfo.quick: Leader of the Maccabean revolt who liberated Jerusalem and established Hanukkah

metadata.agentNotes: Created from Simon the Zealot's perspective - honoring the Maccabean tradition while recognizing how Jesus transformed the Zealot hope for armed liberation into a spiritual kingdom. The Maccabees represent what the Zealots hoped Jesus would be.
